questions.text: Which among the following organs have the least arteriovenous pressure difference?
questions.solution:
Kidneys have the least arteriovenous pressure difference of 14mL/L. Arteriovenous oxygen difference refers to the amount of oxygen taken up by the tissues from the blood. Greater is the oxygen utilized by the tissues, greater will be the arteriovenous oxygen difference.

Other options:

Option A: Brain has an arteriovenous oxygen difference of 62 mL/L.

Option B: Skin has an arteriovenous oxygen difference of 25mL/L.

Option C: Liver has an arteriovenous oxygen difference of 34mL/L.

questions.text: In cases of infant respiratory distress syndrome, there is deficiency of which of the following lipids?
questions.solution:
Dipalmitoylphosphaditylcholine also known as lecithin is deficient in IRDS due to which Surface tension cannot be managed and it increases.

Secreted by type 2 pneumocytes.

choices.text: C fibres are more sensitive to pressure than A fibres
A fibres are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibres
A fibres are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibres
A fibres are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibres

questions.text: A person sleeps on one arm and experiences paresis in the morning but no numbness. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?
questions.solution:
A fibres are more Susceptible to pressure.

B fibres are more susceptible to hypoxia.

C fibres are more susceptible to local anaesthetic.

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in?
questions.solution: The strength of the pulse is determined by the pulse pres­sure and bears little relation to the mean pressure. The pulse is weak ("thready") in shock. It is strong when stroke volume is large; for example, during exercise or after the administra­tion of histamine. When the pulse pressure is high, the pulse waves may be large enough to be felt or even heard by the indi­vidual (palpitation, "pounding heart"). When the aortic valve is incompetent (aortic regurgitation), the pulse is particularly strong, and the force of systolic ejection may be sufficient to make the head nod with each heartbeat. The pulse in aortic regurgitation is called a Corrigan or water-hammer pulse.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with tachypnoea and mental confusion. Blood glucose 350 mg/dI pH=7.0. What is the most likely acid base disorder?
questions.solution:
In Diabetic Ketoacidosis there is an Increased Production of Acetoacetic acid and beta hydroxy Butyric Acid which leads to an increase in plasma concentration of Hydrogen ions leading to Metabolic Acidosis.

For Energy Cells they burn fats. Fats will generate FFA, which breaks ketones, and Can Damage Blood Brain Barrier.

Mainly these are fixed mainly by Bicarbonate.

Stimulation of Carotid Body Chemoreceptors causes increase in the ventilation, which Decreases the arterial Pco2.

questions.text: TENS is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism behind it?
questions.solution: Gate control theory is the mechanism behind Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS). This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers in the vicinity of the injury. The relief is due to activation of innocuous cutaneous mechanoreceptors whose afferents emit collaterals that terminate in the dorsal horn. The activity of these cutaneous mechanosensitive afferents reduce the responsiveness of dorsal horn neurons to their input from nociceptive afferent terminals. This is called the gate-control mechanism of pain modulation.

questions.text: Hormone predominately secreted after 14 days on endometrium is?
questions.solution: After 14 days, the Predominant hormone is Progesterone according to the Ovarian Cycle.

questions.text: Tetanus toxin acts on which of the following?
questions.solution: Tetanus toxin cleaves vesicle-associated membrane protein 2 (VAMP2) also known as synaptobrevin. This molecule is necessary for presynaptic binding and release of neurotransmitters. Thus tetanus toxin prevents transmitter release and effectively blocks inhibitory interneuron discharge which results in unregulated activity in the motor nervous system.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had frequent episodes of seizures. Following is an EEG recording of that boy. Here in this type of seizure 3 doublets per second consisting of a typical spike and wave pattern for about 10 seconds is recorded as follows. Identify the type of seizures.
questions.solution:
• Seizures are divided into partial (focal) seizures and generalized seizures.
  • Generalized seizures can be absent or grand mal seizures.
  • Absence seizures are non-convulsive generalized seizures characterized by momentary loss of consciousness. IN EEG 3/s doublets, each consisting of a typical spike-and-wave pattern of activity that lasts for about 10 s is noted.
  • Grand mal seizure is the most common convulsive generalized seizure. It is associated with sudden onset of contraction of limb muscles (tonic phase) lasting about 30 s, followed by a clonic phase with symmetric jerking of the limbs as a result of alternating contraction and relaxation (clonic phase) lasting 1-2 min. It is also known as tonic-clonic seizures.
  • In the tonic phase EEG activity is fast. In the clonic phase a slow wave followed by a spike is recorded.
  • Partial seizures involve only a small group of neurons. It is either simple or complex type.
  • Simple partial seizure is without loss of consciousness, but Complex one has an altered level of consciousness. Auras typically precedes the onset of partial seizure.

Key Takeaway: Petit mal seizures, also known as absence seizures, are brief lapses of consciousness that typically last for 10-30 seconds. They are most common in children between the ages of 4 and 14.

questions.text: Among the following which touch related sensation is not carried by the dorsal column medial lemniscus pathway?
questions.solution:
• Of the above-mentioned touch sensation, crude touch does not require a high degree of localization and fine gradation of intensity.
  • Crude touch is carried by an anterolateral system which is a primitive system in development. It has poor localization ability as it does not require so.
  • Other three touch sensations such as fine touch, localization and discrimination need a high degree of spatial orientation and gradation. They are carried via the DCML tract.

Key Takeaway: Sensation carried by DCML tract are -

Fine touch

Localization

Discrimination

questions.text: A 11 year old girl child had difficulty keeping her balance while walking. She walks like she is drunk as shown in the picture. The probable cause and site of injury is
questions.solution:
• Due to disturbance in equilibrium walks on broad Based Gait to Maintain Balance. And sways from side to side is ataxic gait seen in cerebellar disorder
  • In a patient with Parkinson's disease, gait is characterized by short shuffling steps, reduced arm swing, and forward-leaning posture known as festinant gait.
  • Stiff, rigid movements due to increased muscle tone is seen in conditions such as cerebral palsy is spastic gait.
  • Due to pain, typically to minimize weight-bearing on an injured limb, an individual walks with a limp known as limping gait.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cerebellum - Ataxic gait
  • Parkinson's disease - festinant gait.
  • cerebral palsy - spastic gait.
  • Injured limb limping gait.

questions.text: A 11 year old baby visited the doctor for a chronic headache. On history & examination the patient was observed hypotensive. After repeated investigations the doctor identified that the baby has genetic deficiency related to lungs. Probably the enzyme deficient is
questions.solution:
• Renin converts the angiotensinogen to angiotensin I. Renin is secreted from the kidney.
  • Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II by Angiotensin converting enzyme I (ACE I) It is secreted in the lungs
  • Aminopeptidase metabolizes the Angiotensin II to angiotensin III in the kidney.
  • So in genetic lung disorder ACE I is deficient.

Key Takeaway: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) plays a crucial role in the lungs, primarily by converting angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor.

questions.text: A 33 year old female patient went to the hospital with increased respiratory rate and shallow respiration. Her respiratory rate is 19 per minute. Tidal volume is 380 ml/ breath. And dead space air is 250 ml. The alveolar ventilation of this female patient is
questions.solution:
• Alveolar ventilation is the amount of air that reaches the gas exchange area in a minute.
  • Pulmonary ventilation is the amount of air exchanged between the atmosphere and lungs.
  • In a tidal volume of air the air that reaches the gas exchange area is alveolar air that is 380-250 ml = 130 ml per breath.
  • Respiratory rate is 19 per minute. 19 * 130 = 2470 ml/min is the alveolar ventilation.

Key Takeaway:

Alveolar Ventilation- [Tidal volume - dead space ]× Respiratory rate.

questions.text: Prothrombin activators activate the prothrombin to thrombin which helps in conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin. Among the following which is not a prothrombin activator?
questions.solution:
• Clotting factor XII is known as the Hageman factor. When it comes in contact with the damaged vessel wall it activates the intrinsic clotting mechanism at the site of injury.
  • Factor V, activated factor X, factor IV (calcium) and phospholipid all together form prothrombin activators.
  • Prothrombin activators activate prothrombin to thrombin which in turn activate fibrinogen to fibrin.
  • This mechanism occurs in both extrinsic and intrinsic clotting mechanisms, so called the final common pathway.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: The haemoglobin is made up of heme and globin. In globin there are four chains. In globin if there are 2alpha and 2 delta chains that type of haemoglobin is
questions.solution:
• In normal adult haemoglobin A there are two polypeptide chains 2 alpha and 2 beta chains. More than 97 % haemoglobin is of this type.
  • About 2.5% of the haemoglobin is haemoglobin A2, in which β chains are replaced by δ chains (α2δ2).
  • In the fetus there is Hb F that is fetal haemoglobin. There are 2 alpha and 2 gamma chains in Hb F. Due to gamma chain affinity for oxygen is increased in haemoglobin.
  • In sickle cell anaemia there is Hb S. The α chains are normal but the β chains have a single substitution of a valine residue for one glutamic acid, leading to sickle cell anaemia.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: In phagocytosis the neutrophils pass through the gap between capillary endothelial cells by a process known as
questions.solution:
• Whenever there is invasion by bacteria in the body, the phagocytic cells reach the target area from the blood vessels.
  • After attaching to the walls of the capillaries, phagocytic cells move via rolling and adhesion. Then Diapedesis Here they insert pseudopods into the junction between the endothelial cells & traverse the basement membrane and escape into extravascular space.
  • The chemotactic agents (C5a, leukotrienes, some polypeptides from mast cells) are released in response to bacterial invasion and attract neutrophils to the infected area.
  • Exocytosis is a process of releasing the cellular contents out side the cell.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 32-year-old male has some hormonal disorder. He was given hormone treatment. Due to administration of hormones the pigmentation is increased in the patient. Which of the following hormone therapy will be responsible for pigmentation?
questions.solution:
• All of the above hormones stimulate the pigmentation in a person following treatment.
  • The melanotropins form alpha and beta melanocyte stimulating hormones from the pituitary gland. Normally they are not secreted in adult humans.
  • Corticotrophs from anterior pituitary gland secretes ACTH hormone
  • In mammals there are melanocytes which express melanotropin-1 receptors.
  • Treatment with MSHs accelerates melanin synthesis, causing readily detectable darkening of the skin in humans. ACTH also binds with melanotropin-1 receptors and stimulate them to produce pigmentary changes.

Key Takeaway:

  • The melanotropins form alpha and beta melanocyte stimulating hormones from the pituitary gland. Normally they are not secreted in adult humans.
  • ACTH also binds with melanotropin-1 receptors and stimulate them to produce pigmentary changes.

questions.text: Which of the following factor inhibit thyroid growth?
questions.solution:
• The alpha subunit of hCG is the same as that of the TSH alpha unit. Large amounts of hCG stimulate the TSH receptor and increase the growth of thyroid gland.
  • Patients with benign or malignant tumors of placental origin, plasma hCG levels can rise so high that they produce mild hyperthyroidism.
  • Thyrocytes express receptors for insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) and epidermal growth factor (EGF). They promote the growth of thyroid gland.
  • Inhibitor of thyroid growth
    • Interferon gamma
    • Tumor necrosis factor alpha
    • Removal of pituitary
    • Chronic inflammation

Key Takeaway:

  • Inhibitor of thyroid growth
    • Interferon gamma
    • Tumor necrosis factor alpha
    • Removal of pituitary
    • Chronic inflammation

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient visited the doctor for some symptoms. Doctor evaluated the patient and found that patient has primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is least likely to be associated symptom in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Primary hyperparathyroidism occurs due to excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone. The cause lies in the parathyroid gland.
  • It causes excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone that produces hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia.
  • Excessive PTH cause excessive bone resorption causing pain in the bones and increased risk of fractures.
  • High level of calcium in the blood causing production of insoluble calcium salts in the form of kidney stones.
  • PTH primarily causes increase in calcium ion and decrease in phosphate ion in the blood. It does not affect the potassium level, so it does not produce hyperkalemia.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: What is the cause of hypokalemia in type 1 diabetic patients?
questions.solution:
• Insulin causes K+ to enter cells, with a resultant lowering of the extracellular K+ concentration. It produces hypokalemia in diabetic acidosis patients.
  • Insulin increases the activity of Na, K ATPase in cell membranes, so that more K+ is pumped into cells.
  • Infusions of insulin and glucose significantly lower the plasma K+ level in normal individuals. It is effective in treatment of hyperkalemia in patients with renal failure.
  • Hyperglycemia cause hypokalemia.
  • Polydipsia does not affect level of potassium ions.

Key Takeaway:

  • Infusions of insulin and glucose significantly lower the plasma K+ level in normal individuals. It is effective in treatment of hyperkalemia in patients with renal failure

questions.text: Secretion of adrenal androgen is controlled by all of the following except?
questions.solution:
• Androgens are the hormones that exert masculinizing effects and they promote protein anabolism and growth.
  • Dehydroepiandrosterone sulphate (DHEAS), androstenedione, testosterone and dihydrotestosterone are androgens.
  • DHEAS and androstenedione are adrenal androgens. Other two are produced in gonads.
  • Secretion of the adrenal androgens is controlled acutely by ACTH and not by gonadotropins.
  • Secretion of gonadal androgen is controlled by gonadotropins directly and GnRH indirectly.
  • However adrenal androgens are also influenced by 17 alpha hydroxylase enzyme in long term.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: In a 28 day regular menstrual cycle 5to14 days are called
questions.solution:
• Menstrual cycle includes endometrial cycle (changes in endometrium) and ovarian cycle (changes in ovary)
  • In menstrual cycle there are three phases
    • Day 1 to 5 are known as the menstrual phase in which bleeding occurs due to shading off of functional endometrium.
    • Day 5 to 14 are known as proliferative phase. In this phase proliferation of endometrium occurs. It is under the influence of estrogen hormone.
    • Day 15 to 28 are known as secretory phase. In this phase secretory changes occur under the main influence of progesterone hormone.
  • In Luteal phase corpus luteum grows after ovulation due to luteinizing hormone. Ovulation occurs at 14th day of cycle in 28 day regular cycle.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Identify the hormone marked by question mark.
questions.solution:
• Above diagram is for hypothalamo-pituitary-gonadal axis. It regulates the secretion of gonadotropins and sex hormones.
  • Secretion of Inhibin occurs by granulosa cells. Inhibin causes inhibition of FSH secretion from anterior pituitary. It does not have any effect on hypothalamic GnRH secretion.
  • Theca cells produce the circulating estrogens that inhibit the secretion of GnRH in the hypothalamus. It also inhibits LH and FSH from anterior pituitary gland.
  • The theca interna cells secretes estrogen that affects the granulosa cells.
  • LH regulates thecal cells, whereas the granulosa cells are regulated by both LH and FSH.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Which of the following stimuli increases salivary secretion?
questions.solution:
• Salivation can also be stimulated or inhibited by nervous signals arriving in the salivatory nuclei from higher centers of the central nervous system, also from other circulatory influences.
  • Major stimulant from CNS is parasympathetic stimulation. It causes an increase in salivary secretion.
  • Sympathetic input slightly increases the saliva (by increasing proteinaceous content).
  • Another factor that affects salivary secretion is the blood supply to the glands.Bradykinin, a potent vasodilator, increases the blood supply and secretion of saliva.
  • Smell and taste of food also increases salivary secretion.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: PAH (para amino hippuric acid) is useful to measure which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The substance which is freely filtered neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules is useful to measure the GFR. Inulin and creatinine are useful to measure GFR.
  • The substance which is freely filtered not reabsorbed but secreted in the tubules is useful to measure renal plasma flow.
  • Renal plasma flow (RPF) equals the amount of a substance excreted per unit of time divided by the renal arteriovenous difference.
  • PAH is the substance used to measure RPF.
  • The excretion rate:- It is the amount of a substance that appears in the urine per unit time.

Excretion rate= urine flow rate (V) × urine concentration of the substance (Ux)

KEY TAKE AWAY

choices.text: Glucose is transported by SGLT 2 at apical membrane in the tubules
Transport of D glucose is greater than L glucose
Phlorhizin inhibit the glucose transport in the kidney

questions.text: True about glucose transport in the kidney is
questions.solution:
• Glucose isomers D glucose and L glucose both are reabsorbed by the tubules in the kidney.
  • Glucose and Na+ bind to the sodium-dependent glucose transporter (SGLT)-2 in the apical membrane in the tubules.
  • The Na+ is then pumped out of the cell into the interstitium, and the glucose exits by facilitated diffusion via glucose transporter (GLUT)-2 into the interstitial fluid.
  • SGLT-2 specifically binds the D isomer of glucose, and the rate of transport of D-glucose is many times greater than that of L-glucose.
  • Glucose transport in the kidneys is inhibited by a plant glucoside phlorhizin, which competes with D-glucose for binding to the carrier.

KEY TAKE AWAY

choices.text: It provides much greater acuity of vision
They are extremely sensitive to light
Responsible for vision in bright light

questions.text: What is true about Rods receptors?
questions.solution:
• There are two types of photoreceptors in the retina: rods and cones.
  • The rods:
    • There are approximately 125 million rods.
    • They are spread throughout the peripheral retina and function best in dim lighting (scotopic vision)
    • The rods are responsible for peripheral and night vision.
    • The rods are extremely sensitive to light.
    • The scotopic visual apparatus resolves the details and boundaries of objects.
  • The cones:
    • The cones have a much higher threshold,
    • The cone system has a much greater acuity
    • It is responsible for vision in bright light and colour vision.
    • It is known as photopic vision

KEY TAKE AWAY

choices.text: Low frequency sound causes maximal activation of basilar membrane near base of cochlea
High frequency sound activates basilar membrane near apex of cochlea
Determination of sound frequencies is known as place principle

questions.text: Among the following list is true related to sound frequencies reaching to the inner ear:
questions.solution:
• Following are the facts related to sound frequency determination by cochlea.
    • Higher frequency sound causes maximal activation of basilar membrane near base of cochlea
    • Low frequency sound activates basilar membrane near apex of cochlea
    • Intermediate frequency sound activates basilar membrane at intermediate distance b/w two extremes
    • Basilar membrane is narrowest and stiffest at the base of cochlea and widest and most compliant at the apex of cochlea

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: Which of the following transport proteins helps in transport of iron out of the basolateral membrane into the interstitial fluid?
questions.solution:
• DMT1 is an apical membrane iron transporter which transports iron in Fe++ form.
  • DCYTB is Fe+3 reductase which converts Fe+3 to Fe+2.
  • HCP1 is heme transporter protein into the enterocyte.
  • Ferroportin 1 is present at the basolateral membrane which allows Fe+2 to enter into the interstitial fluid from the enterocyte.
  • Hephaestin (Heph) which converts Fe2+ to Fe3+.
  • In plasma, Fe3+ is transported bound to the iron transport protein transferrin (TF).

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter plays a crucial role in triggering the vomiting reflex at the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ)?
questions.solution:
• Serotonin (5-HT) released from enterochromaffin cells in the small intestine appears to initiate impulses via 5-HT3 receptors that trigger vomiting.
  • Also, there are dopamine D2 receptors and 5-HT3 receptors in the area postrema and adjacent nucleus of the solitary tract.
  • Emetic agents are their antagonists.
    • Ondanstetron - 5HT3 antagonist
    • Chlorpromazine & haloperidol - D2 antagonists
  • Other neurotransmitters do not have a prominent role in vomiting.

KEY TAKE AWAY
